about.heroSubtitle: A student-led initiative from Gurgaon, India to restore our dark skies
about.quote: I've been fascinated by the night sky for as long as I can remember. But over the years in Gurgaon, I watched the stars disappear one by one. By the time I reached Class 11, I could barely see a dozen stars on a clear night. I asked myself: where did all the stars go?
about.problemDescription1: That question led me down a path of research. I discovered that
about.problemDescription2: 80% of the world's population lives under light-polluted skies
about.problemDescription3: . More than one-third of humanity can never see the Milky Way from their homes.
about.problemDescription4: But the problem went far beyond astronomy. Light pollution:
about.disruptsWildlifeDesc: Birds migrate at wrong times, sea turtles can't find the ocean, nocturnal ecosystems collapse
about.affectsHumanHealthDesc: Sleep disruption, circadian rhythm disorders, linked to serious health issues
about.wastesEnergyDesc: 30% of outdoor lighting in the US is wasted, costing $3.3 billion annually
about.culturalLossDesc: An entire generation growing up never seeing the Milky Way
about.frustrationPara1: As a student in Gurgaon - one of India's most rapidly developing cities - I witnessed firsthand how unchecked urbanization creates environmental problems. But unlike air quality, there was no easy way for citizens to measure light pollution.
about.frustrationPara2: So I taught myself full-stack development and built SkyQI. After months of coding, researching sky quality measurement algorithms, and testing different approaches, I launched a platform where anyone with a smartphone can become a citizen scientist.
about.step1Desc: of the night sky with your smartphone
about.step3Desc: brightness, star count, color temperature, and light pollution
about.step4Desc: SQM value, Bortle Scale rating, NELM, and pollution level
about.forIndividualsDesc: Upload your first sky quality reading and join the citizen science movement
about.forTeachersDesc: Bring citizen science to your classroom with ready-to-use lesson plans
about.forSchoolsDesc: Partner with us for environmental education and citizen science projects
about.founderPara1: SkyQI was founded by a Class 11 student at Amity International School Sector 46, Gurgaon. Passionate about astronomy, environmental science, and technology, they taught themselves full-stack web development to build this platform from scratch.
about.founderPara2: The entire project - including the web application, mobile app, and image analysis algorithms - was built independently, demonstrating that meaningful change doesn't require waiting until you're older. With the right tools and determination, students can create real environmental impact today.
about.founderPara3: This project combines interests in computer science, environmental advocacy, and community engagement, with plans to study these fields at university and continue building technology for social good.
about.visionPara: To empower individuals, communities, and researchers worldwide to measure, understand, and combat light pollution through accessible technology and data-driven advocacy.
about.visionQuote: Look up. Notice. Act. Together, we can restore our night skies.

dashboard.lightPollutionDesc: Light pollution is excessive or misdirected artificial light that brightens the night sky, obscuring stars and affecting ecosystems, human health, and astronomical observations.
dashboard.bortleScaleDesc: The Bortle Dark-Sky Scale measures night sky brightness from Class 1 (excellent dark-sky site) to Class 9 (inner-city sky). Lower numbers indicate darker, better quality skies.
dashboard.sqmMeterDesc: SQM measures sky brightness in magnitudes per square arcsecond. Higher values (21-22) indicate darker skies, while lower values (15-17) indicate significant light pollution.
